channel.title: Comments on: Denominations of Judaism
channel.description: notes on Jewish theology and spirituality

item.title: By: Jon Baker
item.dc:creator: Jon Baker
item.description:
I like "streams". Streams gather tributaries, and flow into rivers, so it doesn't connote a singular centralized organization. Movement tends to connote a singular organization, devoted to one or a set of ideas - the Free Speech Movement, the Reform Movement (now Union for Reform Judaism), etc.
I like R Micha Berger's idea, that Orthodoxy is not a movement, but is a property of various movements: Modern, Mussar, various Chasidish, Yeshivish (their grand rebbe is RYSE?), lehavdil Sabbatean, etc., each with their own institutions.
Conservative and Reform are more centralized, at least in this country - they have singular congregational (USCJ/URJ), rabbinic (RA/CCAR), and educational (HUC/JTSA[/UJ what used to be JTS-LA]) organizations.
